Please promise this is not going to be some backdoor Marxist (ideological) BS, without actually starting by separating Marxist methodology (probably the most important contributor to sociology) and ideology (probably the greatest abuser of sociology for propaganda reasons in the 20th century and into the 21st). Sociology is a minefield of deterministic "progressive" dogmatic philosophy, where extremists try to hijack movements to force their values on other, leading the field itself to be largely ignored by many. I really hope you do this well, because the list of issues I have with sociology at the moment are about as long as the Wehrmacht's advance into the USSR...

> "Social and economic inequalities" specifically worded to emphasize inequality rather than a more neutral term like "distribution".
> Half of the description is about social class when societies are shaped by and manifest as an enormous number of factors. Political institutions manage to get a brief mention, but not religious ones.
> The word "inequality" is used every 20 seconds

This doesn't represent an honest attempt at real knowledge. The entire description manages in only 1 minute to emphasize a very clear bias: inequality is bad. That is an a priori value judgment that has no place in something that wants to call itself even just a "soft science". I'm not disagreeing with that bias, but it doesn't belong in honest academic work, which would be open to the idea that inequality may be a good thing even though we would rather it wasn't.

Basically the intro is setting the stage for the entire series to be a biased, ham-fisted pile of political agenda with no interest in knowing how societies and demographics actually behave unless it conforms to that agenda.

I've never seen so much emphasis on class and inequality since I read the communist manifesto, so I'm tempted to label the agenda "marxist", but 1 minute isn't a lot to go on.

Bottom line, please keep science (as you have been doing) and not an agenda.
